conclusion: The solution aims to analyze whether the particle undergoes linear motion with gradually decreasing acceleration from 1 to 2 seconds based on the v-t graph.

The graph shows velocity (v) in m/s on the y-axis versus time (t) in seconds on the x-axis. The particle's velocity increases from 0 to 1 second (reaching about 20 m/s) and decreases from 1 to 3 seconds (reaching 0 m/s at t=3s).
In a velocity-time graph, the slope at any point represents the instantaneous acceleration, a straight line segment indicates constant acceleration, and a curved line indicates varying acceleration.

Between t=1s and t=2s, the line on the graph is curved, the slope is negative (indicating deceleration), and the absolute value of the slope appears to be decreasing (getting less steep) as time progresses.

When the slope of a v-t graph decreases in magnitude while remaining negative, this means the acceleration is negative but increasing in value (becoming less negative). In other words, the deceleration is decreasing.

Linear motion refers to motion along a straight line (one dimension), which is consistent with the premise that the particle is moving in a straight line. Gradually decreasing acceleration means the acceleration is becoming less positive over time OR deceleration is becoming less negative.

Yes, it is correct to say that the particle undergoes linear motion with gradually decreasing acceleration from 1 to 2 seconds. The curved section of the v-t graph between t=1s and t=2s has a gradually decreasing negative slope, which means the particle is moving in a straight line while its deceleration is gradually decreasing (acceleration becoming less negative).
